resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
wjones127 opened a new pull request #11644:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644


   ## Changes
   
   - [x] Allow Windows R build to detect ARROW_HOME variable and use those binaries
   - [ ] Get Windows R build to find relevant libraries
   - [ ] Update [R developer documentation](https://arrow.apache.org/docs/r/articles/developing.html) to include Windows instructions 


--

wjones127 commented on a change in pull request #11644:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#discussion_r746775382



##########
File path: r/vignettes/developing.Rmd
##########
@@ -154,15 +184,18 @@ You'll first call `cmake` to configure the build and then `make install`. For th
 
 ```{bash, save=run & !sys_install}
 cmake \
+  -G Ninja \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$ARROW_HOME \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR=lib \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_SHARED=OFF \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_STATIC=ON \
   -DARROW_COMPUTE=ON \
   -DARROW_CSV=ON \
   -DARROW_DATASET=ON \
   -DARROW_EXTRA_ERROR_CONTEXT=ON \
   -DARROW_FILESYSTEM=ON \
   -DARROW_INSTALL_NAME_RPATH=OFF \
-  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=ON \
+  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF \

Review comment:
       This library isn't supported on Windows.
   
   Curiosity: why is this part of the std build and not listed as an optional component below? Is it required on Linux or Mac OS?




--

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#issuecomment-965648415


   mingw64 and mingw32 are working, but ucrt64 isn't working for me yet. (Getting `ERROR: loading failed`; it seems to crash 64-bit R.) Maybe I need a UCRT-specific build of R?
   
   I'd like to defer on the ucrt64 instructions and maybe complete them as part of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-13683.


--

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#discussion_r746954043



##########
File path: r/vignettes/developing.Rmd
##########
@@ -154,15 +184,18 @@ You'll first call `cmake` to configure the build and then `make install`. For th
 
 ```{bash, save=run & !sys_install}
 cmake \
+  -G Ninja \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$ARROW_HOME \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR=lib \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_SHARED=OFF \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_STATIC=ON \
   -DARROW_COMPUTE=ON \
   -DARROW_CSV=ON \
   -DARROW_DATASET=ON \
   -DARROW_EXTRA_ERROR_CONTEXT=ON \
   -DARROW_FILESYSTEM=ON \
   -DARROW_INSTALL_NAME_RPATH=OFF \
-  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=ON \
+  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF \

Review comment:
       I would need to double check, but I believe this is the default memory allocator on linux (or it was when we wrote this). 




--

jonkeane commented on a change in pull request #11644:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#discussion_r746961918



##########
File path: r/vignettes/developing.Rmd
##########
@@ -154,15 +184,18 @@ You'll first call `cmake` to configure the build and then `make install`. For th
 
 ```{bash, save=run & !sys_install}
 cmake \
+  -G Ninja \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$ARROW_HOME \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR=lib \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_SHARED=OFF \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_STATIC=ON \
   -DARROW_COMPUTE=ON \
   -DARROW_CSV=ON \
   -DARROW_DATASET=ON \
   -DARROW_EXTRA_ERROR_CONTEXT=ON \
   -DARROW_FILESYSTEM=ON \
   -DARROW_INSTALL_NAME_RPATH=OFF \
-  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=ON \
+  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF \

Review comment:
       Yup, the defaults are (on not-macos): jemalloc, mimalloc, system (in that order, if they are available)
   On macos: mimalloc, jemalloc, system (in that order, if they are available)
   
   So on windows (if jemalloc isn't supported) the order will be: mimalloc, system (in that order)
   
   Because of this, I think we _do_ want it here at least when building on linux or macos. Does it fail gracefully if it's `ON` on windows or does it error completely?




--

wjones127 commented on a change in pull request #11644:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#discussion_r746964769



##########
File path: r/vignettes/developing.Rmd
##########
@@ -154,15 +184,18 @@ You'll first call `cmake` to configure the build and then `make install`. For th
 
 ```{bash, save=run & !sys_install}
 cmake \
+  -G Ninja \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$ARROW_HOME \
   -DCMAKE_INSTALL_LIBDIR=lib \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_SHARED=OFF \
+  -DARROW_BUILD_STATIC=ON \
   -DARROW_COMPUTE=ON \
   -DARROW_CSV=ON \
   -DARROW_DATASET=ON \
   -DARROW_EXTRA_ERROR_CONTEXT=ON \
   -DARROW_FILESYSTEM=ON \
   -DARROW_INSTALL_NAME_RPATH=OFF \
-  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=ON \
+  -DARROW_JEMALLOC=OFF \

Review comment:
       It doesn't currently fail gracefully; it attempts to build jemalloc on Windows and fails. I spent a good part of a day thinking my Arrow build broken until I realized jemalloc just isn't supported on Windows 😢.
   
   I can make a bolded note here that jemalloc should be off for Windows. And then I'd like add something to CMake (or perhaps elsewhere) to not let you try to build jemalloc. 




--

jonkeane commented on pull request #11644:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11644#issuecomment-965733745


   This is really great, I'm going to trigger a crossbow build [1] against this branch. The CI build I'm triggering takes the contents of the devdocs and turns them into a script that is then run (to confirm that the steps here actually produce the outcome we would like. 
   
   You [might have noticed `save=run & macos`](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/r/vignettes/developing.Rmd#L119) or `save=run & linux` 
   
   We don't necessarily have to add windows to this in this PR or right away (though if we are going to defer it, we should make a Jira for it). If you do want to see how this works, basically we [take this special github actions workflow](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/dev/tasks/r/github.linux.revdepcheck.yml) and run it through github actions (there's more complications here, but that's the basic idea)
   
   [1] crossbow, if you're not already familiar is our extend CI system for running CI jobs that don't need to be run on every commit/pr. 


--

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Currently, {{configure.win}} and {{tools/winlibs.R}} have two ways of finding the Arrow C++ library:
 # If {{RWINLIB_LOCAL}} is set, it gets it from that zip file
 # If not, it downloads it

Enable and document a third option for the case when the C++ library has been built locally. This will enable R package developers using Windows machines to make changes to code in the C++ library, build and install it, and then build the R package using it.
fields.summary: [R] Enable R build process to find locally built C++ library on Windows

comments.body: See the {{find_local_source}} function in {{r/inst/linuxlibs.R}} which handles this situation on non-Windows systems, but note that that attempts to build the C++ library, not just find it if it’s already built, and we probably do not want to attempt to script C++ library build on users’ Windows environments.
